bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Wickliffe Rose, September 3, 1921

div1.p: Hanson reports on the yellow fever work in South America. He discusses the irregularity of mail, the effective use of fish for mosquito control, the yellow fever risk of Lima's poorer areas, and public health personnel. Hanson thanks the International Health Board for all of its support to the campaign.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Wickliffe Rose, September 3, 1921
div1.opener:
Chiclayo, September 3, 1921.
Dr. Wicliffe Rose,
General Director, International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York City.
Dear Doctor Rose:
div1.p:
Yesterday I returned from my trip to Panama. I left here on
the fourth of August by way of Lima. On arriving in Lima (together with Dr.
J.H. White) I found that they were still having their farewell parties for the
various embassies and special representatives for the Centennial and that I
could do very little business and decided to take advantage of this time to
go to Panama to attend to certain important personal matters as well as to con-
fer with Col. Fisher an DR. Rucker about the quarantine. Dr. Rucker issued an
order suspending quarantine against Peru, or rather modified it to a six day
observation of passengers from the Peruvian ports, after the time of their
embarcation, but not requiring the usual former quarantine proceedure against
the ship or the permanence in quarantine of the passengers.

While in Panama this office forwarded to me certain mail which had
arrived immediately after I left for Lima. In this mail I received Miss. Read's
letter of July 14, copy of your letter to Dr. White under date of July 16, and
your letter to me dated July 20.

Upon my return to Chiclayo I find in my office the following letters:
Copy of Mr. Bausch's letter of May 7, your letters of May 20, and 21, Copy of
your letter introducing Dr. Frederick L. Hoffman, your letter of May 27, Dr.
Welle's letter of May 23, Miss Read's letters of June 21 (two of them) of June
29 and July 12, as well as yours of July 29th. This will give you some idea of
the irregularity of our mails. To further illustrate this point, I wrote Mrs.
Hanson under date of June 22nd enclosing certain important papers, registering
the letter. This letter was received by her after my arrival in Panama August
2. W.R., I.H.B., September 3, 1921.
15, nearly two months after it had been mailed. I presume that by this time you
have also received some delayed reports and letters. I think I have replied to all
yours except those indicated above.

While in Panama I mailed you a large tube containing a graphic chart of
the work in the Province of Trujillo, together with a map of the Department of Lam-
bayeque. Unfortunately we did not have all the data complete to carry out the mos-
quito curves in the graphic chart, but it is all now down to the base line as
shown on the chart for Trujillo itself. The map of the Department of Lambayeque
will show you better than I can tell you in a letter what the problem was here.
You will note the many small towns, villages and estates which we were unable to
visit personally, and were obliged to leave them for the fever to clean them out.
During the month of August Mr. Pickett and Mr. Seeley have stocked everything with
fish, even the small places on the line from Lambeyeque to Motupe. Up to date in
this Department we have used more than one hundred-forty thousand fish (up to the end of
the month of August) and are still distributing. The results have been beyond my
first expectations. The local Physicians say that at present they are having about
20% less sick calls than they have formerly had for the same corresponding period.
I am not ready to say why. It is probable that the numerous wells which we have
stocked with fish were formerly breeding anopheles. Both the anopheles and culex
index, in addition to that of the stegomya, has been reduced. I feel quite certain
about the security of this Department at the present time.

In Libertad we have distributed more than one hundred thousand fish, and in
Ancash about 30 000, so up to date I think we have about 270 000 fish distributed,
for stegomya control. It is the most effective method of attack but it makes less
expert Inspectors. In our case however we had carried on the other method so long
that we have a very expert group of Inspectors and Visitadores, which is a very
great advantage when added to this new system of working.

On my return from Panama I went ashore in Buena Ventura, Columbia, to see
what the place was like, and to find out what I could in regard to the rumors of the
3. W.R., I.H.B., September 3, 1921.
case of yellow fever there last year. The case referred to seems to have been the
death of the British Consul, who turned yellow before dying. The history in his
case however is that he had been a sufferer from heart and liver trouble, and had
previously had attacks of illness with icterus. This information was given to me
by a Mrs. Smith, the wife of an American Surgeon who has a hospital at La Cumbre.
The natives with whom I talked gave no history of any illness of that kind for
several years, and I am inclined to believe that the rumors of last years case or
cases are unfounded. I speak of this because I discussed this matter with Dr. White
and suggested to him that this place be investigated.

Buena Ventura is a very small place, quite distant from other towns, one
which has every evidence of being infested with malaria. It is very swampy, having
numerous low wet areas which could well be prolific breeders of anopheles, and it
could happen that a case of pernicious malaria would be mistaken for yellow fever
by persons who are inexpert in the diagnosis of either. While there I made one of
my customary investigations;viz. that of inspection of the holy water in the church.
There was no breeding in it, In this section wherever the stegomya breeding has
been high we have always found stegomyalarvae in the holy water.

On the way south we stopped at the Port of Pizarro in the Province of
Tumbes. I went ashore and went up to Tumbes (which is the most northerly province
of Peru, bounded on the north by Ecuador). We have had some men doing anti-stegomya
work there, and apparently with fairly good results. I found no breeding in my brief
inspection. However I left orders for the man there to stock all doubtful places
with fish. Tumbes (the term and capital of the Province) is within one-half hours ride of the Ecuadorean frontier. I do
not think that it will be necessary to keep up the work there. Dr. Carter and I are
of the opinion that this place was immunized by the epidemic of 1918 & '19.

In Paita I made further inquiries, but thereit seems that there has been
nothing of a suspicious nature since our last year's campaign. This in further
conformation of former reports.

While in Panama, I found that Mr. Dunn the Entomoligist to the Panama
Canal was to be let out on a count of the reduction of force, and that he was
about to be taken over by the United States Public Health Service for work in
4. W.R., I.H.B., September 3, 1921.
the States. In as much as I only expected to keep Mr. Corrigan and Pickett until I
should be back to go over the situation with them, I thought it would be well to
take advantage of Mr. Dunn and bring him down for a double purpose; that of using
him both as Inspector and of carrying out properly the observations which we have
started on the stegomya. Dr. White knows of this, at least some of it. I wanted to
prove why it is that stegomya only breed in artificial containers, and I thought
that we were on the track of the reason why. It seemed to me it might be considered
worth while to be able to include this in writing the final chapter of the history
of yellow fever on the Pacific Coast of South America. The expense will be very
small relatively, as my plan is to devote only a part of his time to this problem.
Mr. Dunn has done field work with me in Panama and did some very good work during
the war in his Army Service. Lately he had a very important problem going in the
Board of Health Laboratory of the Canal Zone, on the tick in its relation to re-
lapsing fever, as well as a very good series of observation on the stegomya which
was more or less along the same lines as I have been working here in Peru.

If you do not approve of this line kindly cable me on receipt of this and
I will limit his work to that of supervising inspector. I offered him $400.00 per
month but he held out for $425.00, and expenses, on the grounds that this was a
brief temporary assignment, and would break his connections with work in the states.

Mr. Corrigan and Sr. Sainz are continuing their work in the Department of
Ancash together with Dr. Caballero. A few days ago we sent them ten thousand fish
from here, because of the difficulty in getting fish in that section. As soon as I
have things lined up in this office I shall start south on a tour of inspection
going as far as Lima, expecting to reach Lima about the middle of October. If it
can be done I will try to get them to do stegomya work in Lima for the balance of
the year. As I have often stated before it now depends on what has happened to the
south- of the north we are certain. The only place of which I still have any doubts
is of Lima and Callao, but especially of Lima. All towns to the north of that we
will have controlled before the end of the year. We are taking no chances on any-
thing north of Lima and Callao. The protions of Lima which are the occasion of
5. W.R., I.H.B., September 3, 1921.
uncertainty are the poorer subdivisions where there is an insufficient water
supply, such as the Victoria section, Chirimoya, and “Abajo la Puente” a poor
section on the north side of the river. In Callao Mr. Richardson and one of the
Inspectors which I had last year Sr. Mauro Torres U., have been doing some anti stegomya work,
directly under Mr. Wrightson, but I believe this has been suspended. If I can
get this also placed under my control I shall have them start a vigorous fish
campaign, and may be able to spare some of the Inspectors from the northern terri-
tory for this work.

The only loophole that I can see for trouble during the coming warm
weather would be some smouldering focus about Lima and Callao,- the northern
Departments will be safe due to the work which we are doing and will continue
to sun do. The north is well organized, with experienced employees, which will
enable me to keep a closer watch on Lima and Callao than has been possible up to
date.

The winter in Lima has been so cold that I am inclined to believe that
even if some case had gotten through the infection most probably has died out, and
the outbreak would have to be from some place in the north, which at the present
time we do not think possible.

I will take up the different points in the letters referred to above, in
a separate communication.

I want to express my appreciation and gratitude for the generous support
which the International Health Board has given in this campaign, and especially
to you personally for the broad an generous view you have taken of our efforts.
Had it not been for your help we would have lost the campaign altogether. I shall
endeavor to make the Government understand this.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Henry Hanson,
Director of Campaign.
